editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

the glory of god, if they were imploied as they ought: yet neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e they remaine vnfruitfull, through their owne idleneÅ¿Å¿e, and negligence. Tit. 3 Vnder the word excellencie or dignitie, are comprehended all thoÅ¿e notable titles with which the Å¿cripture doth Å¿et forth the miniÅ¿try, vnder the word hard, all difficulties. Tim. 2 AlÅ¿o in the 2. Timoth. 2. Wee reade,Gen. 26 VVhat bee the occaÅ¿ions of enuie. that IÅ¿aac in the time of a grieuous famine, went vnto Abimelech King of the PhiliÅ¿tines in Gerar, and that GOD hauing bleÅ¿Å¿ed his Å¿tore, in making his flockes of Sheepe and Cattell to encreaÅ¿e, and all that hee poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed: It is Å¿ayde afterwardes in the HyÅ¿torie, that the PhiliÅ¿tines enuied him: where wee maye Å¿ee an apparaunt matter of theyr enuie, which was that they enioyed not Å¿uch bleÅ¿Å¿inges as IÅ¿aac did: Wherevppon they made a great tumult, for the PhiliÅ¿tines troubled IÅ¿aac, they Å¿topped vp all his Welles, with which hee watered his flockes, and their rage was Å¿o great, that for to appeaÅ¿e and allay the Å¿ame, IÅ¿aac was conÅ¿trained to depart from them. And the reaÅ¿on is added by Abimelech himÅ¿elfe, where hee
Å¿pake on this Å¿ort vnto IÅ¿aac: Get thee from vs for thou art mightier then we a great deale. This faire reaÅ¿on might make Abimelech aÅ¿hamed, and all his Subiectes, becauÅ¿e it did proceede from the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of the minde.

VVhat was the cauÅ¿e, that Rachel conceyued Å¿uch an hatred agaynÅ¿t her Å¿iÅ¿ter Lea? Gen. 30. And murmured Å¿o much agaynÅ¿t her husbande, that Å¿hee her Å¿elfe Å¿ayde, that Shee Å¿houlde die, if hee gaue her not children. The reaÅ¿on is Å¿et downe, becauÅ¿e Rachel Å¿awe Å¿hee bare Iacob no children, as her Å¿iÅ¿ter Lea did (for which cauÅ¿e Å¿hee was a reproach vnto thoÅ¿e that liued at that time) Å¿hee purÅ¿ued with enuie her Å¿iÅ¿ter Lea, who was in great reputation amongÅ¿t all at that time, becauÅ¿e that barrenneÅ¿Å¿e was reproachfull to Women, and that was the cauÅ¿e that Rachel was Å¿o enraged agaynÅ¿t her Å¿iÅ¿ter Lea, in that Å¿hee was not Å¿o fruitfull as Å¿hee.

Let vs go forward, if this vice creepe into men of warre, or into Courtes, or into Kingdomes, or into the Church of God, it Å¿tirreth vp incredible miÅ¿chiefes. In warre among them that make profeÅ¿Å¿ion to carrie armes. Who can Å¿peake of halfe of thoÅ¿e troubles that it kindleth? whereof ca â€¢ e that Å¿trife and contention betwixt the men of
Ephraim and Gideon, then when Gideon purÅ¿ued the reÅ¿t of the Madianites, that he had in chaÅ¿e? It proceeded from no other cauÅ¿e, but that Gideon had done an exployt of warre moÅ¿t memorable, which had neuer beene ended but lamentably, had not Gideon, (perceiuing well the occaÅ¿ion) pacified them, attributing vnto them the better part of the victorie,Iudg. 8 Eunie deÅ¿troyeth all where it entreth. as wee maye reade.

If it creepe into Courtiers, it is neuer Å¿atisfied, but with the death of thoÅ¿e that it dooth enuie. There is a notable example hereof among the gouernours that Darius had appoynted ouer his Realme.Dan. 6 And ouer thoÅ¿e three Rulers that had the ouerÅ¿ight of the hundreth and twentie gouernours: for wee reade, that Darius hauing appoynted Daniel one of the three ouer the hundreth and twentie gouernours, hee loued him Å¿o well, that hee thought to haue Å¿et him ouer the whole Realme, that he Å¿hould bee the Å¿econde after him, inÅ¿omuch, that the other Gouernours beganne to enuie, and to beare Å¿uch a vehement iealouÅ¿ie towardes him, partlie becauÅ¿e hee was Å¿o beloued of the King, and partlie becauÅ¿e of the IewiÅ¿h Religion, that they founde out a meanes to accuÅ¿e him of vnfaithfulneÅ¿Å¿e towardes the King, becauÅ¿e hee
would not call vppon the King Darius, according to the decree that the enemies of Daniel had cauÅ¿ed to bee made. What came to paÅ¿Å¿e? hee was caÅ¿t into the Lions Denne to bee deuoured of them, and it had Å¿o come to paÅ¿Å¿e, if GOD had not Å¿hewed a maruailous token of his prouidence in defending, in reÅ¿trayning the nature of thoÅ¿e furious BeaÅ¿tes, who in Å¿teede of tearing him in peeces, did him no harme at all: but the other his accuÅ¿ers, beeing by the commaundement of the King caÅ¿t into this Denne, with theyr Wiues and Children, were deuoured euen vnto theyr bones, before they were come vnto the bottome of the Denne. If it infecteth Kings, or enters into them vnto whome their Kingdomes may come by any meanes, this furious BeaÅ¿t doth Å¿hewe her Å¿elfe more cruell: for Å¿hee doth not onely procure the death of them vppon whome Å¿hee faÅ¿tneth her Å¿elfe, but Å¿hee is Å¿o outragious, that Å¿hee proÅ¿ecuteth vnto death, all thoÅ¿e whom Å¿he Å¿o mortally hateth: yea, euen to baniÅ¿h out of the places, the brute beaÅ¿ts, where thoÅ¿e whom they enuie doo remaine, yea, and ouerthrow the place it Å¿elfe, Å¿uch is their inÅ¿atiable enuie. AmongÅ¿t other examples we may read, that when Saul had a long time Å¿ought Dauid to put him to death,2. Sam, 21. fearing
leaÅ¿t hee Å¿hould gette away his Kingdome from him, it is there Å¿aide, that one of the Å¿eruaunts of Saul named Doeg, deÅ¿iring to gratifie his MaiÅ¿ter, came and tolde Saul that Dauid was in the Towne of Nob, and that the prieÅ¿t Ahimelech had giuen vnto him the Sworde of Goliah. Saul Å¿ent to Å¿eeke Ahimelech, hee Å¿pake reproachfully vnto him, and called him traitour, and Å¿ayde that hee hadde conÅ¿pired againÅ¿t him with Dauid: vnto whome when Ahimelech had aunÅ¿wered, that neither hee nor Dauid did conÅ¿pire, but that hee was his Sonne in lawe, and a faythfull Å¿eruant, and that hee had onely asked counÅ¿ell of the Lorde for him. Then the gall and venome of enuie which was in the heart of Saul, aboundantly powred foorth it Å¿elfe, for hee cauÅ¿ed not onely Ahimelech to bee Å¿laine, but alÅ¿o foureÅ¿core and foure PrieÅ¿tes with him, AlÅ¿o Nob the Cittie of the PrieÅ¿tes, Å¿mote hee with the edge of the Sworde, both man and woman, both childe and Å¿uckling, both Oxe, AÅ¿Å¿e and Sheepe, which were in the Cittie. To go forwarde, if it once enters into Brothers and SiÅ¿ters, which haue iÅ¿Å¿ued out of one bellie, it cannot bee kept backe by this fraternitie, which is the greateÅ¿t bond of loue as poÅ¿Å¿ibly may bee, it breaketh out oftentimes
by a moÅ¿t cruell murther of them which are ioyned together in conÅ¿anguinitie: wee may propoÅ¿e two examples hereof, one of the Brethren of IoÅ¿eph, Gen. 37. of whome wee reade, when hee was deadly hated of his Brethren (becauÅ¿e Iacob theyr Father loued him, and alÅ¿o for his Dreames, by the interpretation whereof, his Father, his Mother, and his brethren, might vnderÅ¿tand, that one day he Å¿hould bee preferred before them) his Brethren conÅ¿pired his death, and at length to Å¿atisfie theyr enuie, they Å¿olde him, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that theyr enuie was Å¿o violent, that although they knewe for certaintie, that he Å¿hould prooue a great Prince, who might afterward Å¿tande them in Å¿teede, yet they had rather haue putte him to death, then to haue Å¿eene him in Å¿uch an eÅ¿tate. The other may bee taken from Caine, who paÅ¿Å¿ed further: for the HiÅ¿torie maketh mention, that Å¿eeing the Å¿acrifice which hee offered, was not Å¿o accepted of GOD as his Brother Abels was, hee moÅ¿t cruelly maÅ¿Å¿acred him. Moreouer, the enuious man doth not onely putte to death thoÅ¿e whome he doth enuie, but Å¿ometime hee layeth violent handes euen vppon himÅ¿elfe, as Å¿ome haue noted: and for proofe whereof, they haue Å¿et downe the example of Achitophell, 2. Sam 17 of whome
wee may reade, who verie much greeued, that the counÅ¿aile of HuÅ¿hhai was preferred before his, hee went home and hanged himÅ¿elfe. To be breefe, if an enuious man could Å¿et himÅ¿elfe againÅ¿t God, hee would doo it: and wee may verie well Å¿ay, that enuie hath reached Å¿o farre in the perÅ¿on of the Scribes and PhariÅ¿ies, and many others, of whome wee reade in the GoÅ¿pel, who although they were more then conuinced in their conÅ¿ciences, that IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t was God, being Å¿o inchaunted with this poyÅ¿on of enuie, they deuiÅ¿ed all meanes that they could to putte him to death, accuÅ¿ing him, that hee Å¿ayde he was God, and in the ende by this falÅ¿e accuÅ¿ation they crucified him. BeÅ¿ides, enuie is the Å¿ole cauÅ¿e of th â€¢
â€¢ eÅ¿truction of thoÅ¿e which are poyÅ¿oned therwith, the onely ouerthrow of kingdomes, if it once dooth infinuate it Å¿elfe into the hearts of them which haue the gouernment of the Å¿ame: and it is no leÅ¿Å¿e merciful vnto the Church of God, if the leaders thereof giue way vnto it. And becauÅ¿e that Sathan, who is the true Father of enuie, and the mortall enemie of the Å¿aluation of men,Enuie in the church hurteth as much as in any other Å¿tate. endeuoureth with al his foce to increaÅ¿e his Kingdom, and to deÅ¿troy Gods people, knowing that if there be any in whoÅ¿e heart this accurÅ¿ed paÅ¿Å¿ion is planted and ingraued, it is in the heart of PaÅ¿tors
whereby hee may gaine moÅ¿t, and the more aduance his kingdome, and diminiÅ¿h Gods inheritance. Then it may Å¿o fall out, that hee that is thus poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed with enuie, in Å¿teede of Å¿eeking the glorie of God, and the diÅ¿charge of his dutie, hee will Å¿eeke his owne, neither will hee bee content to liue peaceably amongÅ¿t his fellow brethren, if hee Å¿hall perceiue that they excell him in any grace, whereby he may profite himÅ¿elfe, and learne of them, and that the Church may be greatly edified, but he rather taketh delight, that both he and the Church Å¿hould be depriued of Å¿uch men, then patiently to beare, that the opinion which is conceiued of him, or which hee perÅ¿wadech himÅ¿elf men conceiue of his gifts, Å¿hould any way be impaired by others. And to conclude, Å¿eeing there is no Å¿uch way to promote the glorie of God, as by the miniÅ¿trie of his worde, prouided alwayes that thoÅ¿e that haue the charge therof, to preach the Å¿ame, bee voyde of all Å¿iniÅ¿ter and corrupt affections, and eÅ¿pcially of this enuie: Å¿o there is no inÅ¿trument which doth more diminiÅ¿h the Kingdome of God, and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h that of Sathan, as when the PaÅ¿tors Å¿uffer themÅ¿elues to bee carried away with theÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ions. Therefore wee muÅ¿t deteÅ¿t as much as poÅ¿Å¿ibly wee can, this horrible monÅ¿ter Enuie, and to the
end we may the more abhorre the Å¿ame: let vs conÅ¿ider, that he that yeeldeth therunto, doth but procure his owne torment. Furthermore, in reÅ¿pect of him which is followed with enuie,How enuy may be corrected. hee is Å¿o far many times from being hurt, that that vertue is increaÅ¿ed in him, which others goe about to diminiÅ¿h. And this is that which Propertius would Å¿ignifie when he Å¿ayth, that an enuious man hath Å¿o many tormentors, that doo iuÅ¿tly puniÅ¿h him, as hee whome hee dooth enuie hath commenders. And verily, as enuious men doo procure prayÅ¿e and commendation vnto them, whome they gnawe vppon with theyr enuie, they do but heap vp the torment of their minde, and cauÅ¿e their owne Å¿hame. as ChriÅ¿oÅ¿tome Å¿heweth vppon Mathew. O Enuie, which art alwaies an enemie to thy Å¿elfe, for he that enuieth, maketh himÅ¿elfe as infamous, as hee cauÅ¿eth him to hee glorious whome hee proÅ¿ecuteth with enuie. And lette vs adde this, to comfort them which are troubled with the enuie borne againÅ¿t them, that moÅ¿t notable Å¿aying of Propertius, that the pricke of enuie ought to Å¿tirre vppe men more to the exerciÅ¿e of vertue. Iacob hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer Iordane with his Å¿taffe, had neuer returned with great bandes, if the enuie of EÅ¿aw had not Å¿tirred him vp, and exerciÅ¿ed him.

IoÅ¿eph had not beene a commaunder in Egypt, if the enuie of his brethren had not Å¿old him. For it is written, hee cannot bee Abell, that is not exerciÅ¿ed with the malice of Caine. With theÅ¿e things alÅ¿o wee may ioyne that which Cicero Å¿aith againÅ¿t Catiline, that enuie gotten by vertue, ought not to be counted enuie, but vertue. And this ought as well to bee applied to thoÅ¿e which do purÅ¿ue others with enuie, Å¿omewhat to reÅ¿traine them, as to thoÅ¿e which are enuied, the more to encourage them cheerefully to goe forward and perÅ¿euere in well dooing.

div.head: The Å¿econd Booke.

div.p:
SEeing that now wee haue Å¿ufficiently declared the dignitie of the MiniÅ¿trie, and the great difficulties which are to be found in the Å¿ame, as wel in regard of thoÅ¿e vertues with which they are to be indued, who doo aÅ¿pire vnto it, as in reÅ¿pect of thoÅ¿e vices which they are to auoyd: Let vs come now to thoÅ¿e difficulties, which doo offer themÅ¿elues as well in teaching the word of God vnto the people, as in defending the Å¿ame, by encountring with heriticques, of whome Å¿ome doo falÅ¿ifie the Å¿ame: Å¿ome doo
mingle it with their rayling, & others defiles it with their GloÅ¿Å¿es. TheÅ¿e then be the two points, which S. Paul doth principally require in MiniÅ¿ters, when he Å¿aith: That they muÅ¿t be apt to teach, and haue knowledge to confute the gainÅ¿ayers. Of which point wee are now to Å¿peake in order, but before we enter into the diÅ¿courÅ¿e of them, let vs obÅ¿erue that, Å¿eeing that the queÅ¿tion is, how to make a perfect PaÅ¿tor in his charge, that we muÅ¿t keepe that order which haue been obÅ¿erued a long time, as we Å¿ee in a CannoÌ„ which was taken froÌ„ the fourth councell of Carthage, where S. AuÅ¿tin Å¿at, which Å¿aith thus. He that is to be made MiniÅ¿ter, firÅ¿t of all muÅ¿t bee examined whether he be wiÅ¿e by nature, docible, temperate in his maners, ChaÅ¿te in an holy life, Å¿ober, watchfull, prouident in his affaires, humble, affable, mercifull, Å¿o much for his behauiour. Afterward it followeth for his learning: that he muÅ¿t be wel â€¢ learned, inÅ¿tructed in the lawe of the Lord, vnderÅ¿tanding aright the Å¿ence of the Scriptures, exerciÅ¿ed in the doctrine of the Church, He that will imbrace the charge of the miniÅ¿tery muÅ¿t be of good life, learned, and alwairs diligent. and aboue all, that he doth Å¿imply hold all the Articles and documents of faith. Where we may perceiue by this Canon, that in MiniÅ¿ters, the Å¿uffiicencie of learning muÅ¿t bee ioyned with honeÅ¿ty of manners, and that by good reaÅ¿on: for it is not Å¿ufficient that a MiniÅ¿ter Å¿houlde bee a good man, fearing God, and vnfurniÅ¿hed of thoÅ¿e
partes which are neceÅ¿Å¿arie for the execution of this charge: neither on the other Å¿ide, it Å¿ufficeth that one Å¿hould be learned and profounde in knowledge, and skilfull, and neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e bee of a wicked life. For as wicked manners with knowledge, ought to cauÅ¿e men to be kept backe from this charge, Å¿o a good life, and an honeÅ¿t coÌ„uerÅ¿ation, ioyned with inÅ¿ufficiencie, and vnfitneÅ¿Å¿e, ought to make others to be put by, & excluded. To theÅ¿e two points let vs ioyne a third, that it is not Å¿ufficient to bee capable to preach the worde of God, and to be of a good life, but beÅ¿ides theÅ¿e two, that they put that in prac-which they teach, and that they vÅ¿e diligence and induÅ¿trie, in imploying the gifts which they haue receiued of the Lord, for the edificatioÌ„ of his church. Wherfore let them continually Å¿et before their eies, this excellent Å¿entence of S. Gregorie, which ought to bee as a GlaÅ¿Å¿e, daily to behold all the partes of their dutie. He muÅ¿t (Å¿aith he) Å¿eriouÅ¿ly conÅ¿ider, what it is, that he that deÅ¿ires this charge, coÌ„meth vnto, and after hauing attained the Å¿ame, how he liueth: alÅ¿o he muÅ¿t Å¿ee, how liuing well, he teacheth, how teaching wel, he learneth euery day his own weakneÅ¿Å¿e, for feare leaÅ¿t that this great humilitie Å¿houlde cauÅ¿e him to auoide this charge: wherein being placed, his life muÅ¿t not bee contrarie to the dignitie of the Å¿ame: and beeing in this
charge, although hee be of a good life, he muÅ¿t not faile in doctrine. And if he be learned, he muÅ¿t not bee proude: and in Å¿umme, beeing filled with all vertue, he muÅ¿t not raÅ¿hly attempt this charge, vnleÅ¿Å¿e he be conÅ¿trained thereunto: and if he be voyde of vertue, hee muÅ¿t take heede that hee approacheth not vnto the Å¿ame, although hee bee conÅ¿trained. Let vs enter then into the diÅ¿courÅ¿e of this propertie of teaching requiÅ¿ite in the PaÅ¿tour. Let vs obÅ¿erue, that it conÅ¿iÅ¿teth principally in three poyntes: whereof the firÅ¿t is to teach the worde of God vnto the people, and to adminiÅ¿ter the Sacraments. The Å¿econd is, to confute the doctrines of falÅ¿e prophets, and teachers. The thirde, to exhort the people to repentance.The propertie of preaching do conÅ¿iÅ¿t in 3. points. 1. To preach the worde of God. 2. To conuince the gainÅ¿ayers 3. To exhort and reproue. 1. Tim. 3. Tit. 1

TheÅ¿e three poynts may bee verie clearely gathered of that which Saint Paule Å¿peaketh in Tim. and Tit. where hee Å¿ayth, That a BiÅ¿hop muÅ¿t be apt to teach: it is not meant that this qualitie muÅ¿t bee a thing forged in the ayre, it muÅ¿t bee imployed in the inÅ¿truction of the people: and although Å¿aint Paul Å¿peaketh not at all in that place, of the adminiÅ¿tration of the Sacramentes, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿eeing that the adminiÅ¿tration of the Sacraments, dooth depende vppon the preaching of the worde, hee that preacheth the worde, may alÅ¿o adminiÅ¿ter the Sacraments:

The firÅ¿t is, that IehoÅ¿aphat willing to purge the high places of Iuda, of Idolatrie, hee did appoynt Leuites and PrieÅ¿tes, who Å¿houlde teach Iuda, hauing with them the Booke of the Lawe of the Lorde, and they went about through all ye Cities of Iuda, and taught the people.Ezech. 44 The Å¿econd is in Ezechiel, where wee reade, that the Lord reprouing the Iewes, becauÅ¿e they had eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in the Å¿eruice of God, thoÅ¿e that ought not to be receiued, hee Å¿ayeth in the 15. verÅ¿e of the Å¿ame Chapter, that the PrieÅ¿ts of the Leuits, the Å¿onnes of Zadok, that kept the cha â€¢ ge of his Sanctuarie, when the children of IÅ¿rael went aÅ¿tray from him, that they Å¿hould come neer to him to Å¿erue him, & they Å¿hould Å¿taÌ„d before him to offer the fat, & the blood, and yt they Å¿hould adminiÅ¿ter ye which he had appointed. And in the 23. ve. it is added, yt they
Å¿hould teach the people, the difference betweene the holy and prophane, and cauÅ¿e theÌ„ to d â€¢ Å¿cern between the vncleane & the clean. Let vs come to thoÅ¿e proofes of the newe TeÅ¿tament, which are more euident. It is Å¿aid in the Acts,Acts 2 that Peter and Paul, preached repentance, and remiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿ins, & they that heard it, were pricked in their harts, & Å¿aid vnto Peter, and the other apoÅ¿tles, Men & brethren, what Å¿hall we do? Then Peter Å¿aid vnto them, Amend your liues, and be baptized euery one of you, in the name of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, for the remiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿innes, and yee Å¿hall receiue the gift of the holy GhoÅ¿t. Againe, when Saint Paul in the 20. of the Acts, Acts 20 dooth reckon vppe the Å¿umme of his ApoÅ¿tleÅ¿hip, he Å¿aith vnto the Elders of the Church of EpheÅ¿us, That hee kept backe nothing from them that was profitable, but had Å¿hewed them, and taught them openly, and throughout euerie houÅ¿e, witneÅ¿Å¿ing to the Iewes, & alÅ¿o to the Grecians, the repentance towards God, and faith towarde our Lord IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t.Acts 26 And in the 26. Paul being before king Agrippa, did recount al his office, he Å¿aith, That aÅ¿Å¿oone as euer he was called
to be an ApoÅ¿tle, by an heaueÌ„ly viÅ¿ion which appeared vnto him as hee was going to DamaÅ¿cus, hee Å¿hewed the Å¿ame firÅ¿t vnto them which were at DamaÅ¿cus, and IeruÅ¿alem, and throughout all the coaÅ¿ts of Iuda, and to the Gentiles, that they Å¿hould repent, and turne to God, and do works worthie amendment of life.The proof of the Å¿econd point. 1. King. 18. Let vs proue the Å¿econd poynt by other places of Scripture, that is, that a PaÅ¿tor muÅ¿t bee able to confute the erroneous doctrine of falÅ¿e teachers: of which we haue examples of the Prophets, and ApoÅ¿tles. FirÅ¿t, we Å¿ee in the firÅ¿t Booke of the Kings, that the Prophet Elias did Å¿hewe vnto Achab, and to the people of IÅ¿rael, that the prophets of Baal, (which the ignoraunt people helde for true Prophets) were falÅ¿e Prophets, and he himÅ¿elfe did conuince them of falÅ¿hoode, by that Å¿acrifice which they had choÅ¿en to make knowne, which of them two (hee or they) were falÅ¿e Prophets. In the Å¿econd place, we reade in Ieremie, Iere. 14 that the Prophet Ieremie by the commaundement of God, did confute the propheÅ¿ies
of the falÅ¿e Prophets, who affirmed that God would not puniÅ¿h IeruÅ¿alem, nether by the Å¿worde, nor by famine. And in the 28. of the Å¿ame Prophet,Chap. 25 a certaine falÅ¿e prophet named Hananiah, Å¿hewing the people, that God had broken the yoke of Nabuchadnezzar ye

VVhen it it is there Å¿et downe, that Ieremiah had the worde of the Lorde to the contrarie, who by Gods commaundement, put him backe, Å¿aying vnto him in the 15. verÅ¿e of the Å¿ame chapter: Heare now Hananiah, the Lord hath not Å¿ent thee, but thou makeÅ¿t this people

Wee reade likewiÅ¿e, howe that Ezechiel did beate downe the falÅ¿e Prophets and prophiteÅ¿Å¿es, who Å¿educed the people declaring vnto them peace in the name of the Lord, then when hee was purpoÅ¿ed to take vengeance vppon them for their Å¿innes, Å¿aying: VVo vnto the fooliÅ¿h Prophets, that follow their owne Å¿pirit, & haue Å¿eene nothing. So that the beÅ¿t way for euerie one, is to bee acquainted with his owne voyce, and Å¿o to order his Å¿peech: but vnto whome GOD hath giuen a fitte and agreeable voyce, hee muÅ¿t take great heede in gouerning the Å¿ame: for Å¿eeing that Å¿uch a voyce is one of the greateÅ¿t giftes of GOD that a Preacher can haue, hee muÅ¿t beware that hee dooth apply the Å¿ame to the beÅ¿t vÅ¿e: but howe Å¿hall hee vÅ¿e it? principally in preaching, hee Å¿hall keepe alwayes the Å¿ame tenour Å¿ufficiently high, that all may vnderÅ¿tande euerie worde that hee doth vtter:A good voyce in a preacher, is a Å¿ingular gift of God. when hee alÅ¿o Å¿hall Å¿peake diÅ¿tinctly and leyÅ¿erly, for to Å¿peake aloude and faÅ¿t, the hearer cannot vnderÅ¿tand, and by conÅ¿equent, not conceiue that which the Preacher Å¿ayth.Sen. in EpiÅ¿t. Seneca Å¿peaking of that manner which Cicero vÅ¿ed in the pronouncing of his Orations, that hee Å¿pake for the moÅ¿t parte diÅ¿tinctly and readily, that is, it came from him with great eaÅ¿e, not haÅ¿tly, that in him there was a kinde of eaÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, no celeritie: afterwarde hee addeth: I deÅ¿ire then in an Orator, that his wordes may paÅ¿Å¿e from him without any lette, and that hee pronounceth his
words, as though they Å¿hould flow from him. And this is that which a preacher Å¿hould labour for in the pronouncing of Sermons vnto the people, becauÅ¿e of the great profit that commeth thereof.

Lette vs ioyne vnto this another Å¿aying of the Å¿ame Authour, that the ornaments of learning and eloquence, doo conÅ¿iÅ¿t in the fitte pronuntiation and geÅ¿ture of the bodie, with which hee that is furniÅ¿hed, hee may aÅ¿Å¿aile the hearers three manner of wayes.The profit of the voyce when it is ordered as it ought to be FirÅ¿t in pearcing into theyr eares. Secondly, in delighting them. Thirdly, in gayning theyr hearts. And heere wee may obÅ¿erue two poyntes verie profitable for the preacher. The firÅ¿t is concerning pronuntiation, the which as experience teacheth, hath great force in teaching, eÅ¿pecially when it is well ordered. For although a man bee profounde in knowledge, yet if hee hath no grace in pronouncing, hee can little edifie, but if hee bee garniÅ¿hed with a milde Å¿pirite, and with a grace of pronuntiation, hee doth maruailouÅ¿ly edifie, although hee handle not deepe and profounde matters.

But well to order, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e this voyce, what muÅ¿t hee doo? hee muÅ¿t oftentimes chaunge the Å¿ame, according
to the occaÅ¿ions which may bee offered, that is, in Å¿peaking Å¿ometime high and Å¿ometime lowe but in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that he may be vnderÅ¿tood of all, if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible. Moreouer, hee muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, when he Å¿peaketh of Å¿weet & delightfull things (as of the promiÅ¿es of god) that he do likewiÅ¿e in Å¿ome Å¿ort expreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿weetneÅ¿Å¿e of them, by his voice: and wheÌ„ he Å¿peaketh of fearefull things, which are to aÅ¿toniÅ¿h the hearers, as with the iudgements of god, and threatnings againÅ¿t men, it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie to force the voice, and to make the hearer as it were,When a preacher doth denounce the iudgements of God, hee muÅ¿t Å¿peak harÅ¿hly. When he Å¿peaketh of the promiÅ¿es of God, pleaÅ¿antly. to tremble at the denuntiation of them. For in truth, as Cicero hath very well Å¿aid, it is a fault in an Orator, when hee Å¿heweth a thing full of pleaÅ¿ure and delight, with Å¿orrowfull words, as when hee pronouÌ„ ceth a baÅ¿e thing, with a pleaÅ¿ant and delicate Å¿tile. The other point is, when he Å¿peaketh of any thing done, he muÅ¿t vÅ¿e Å¿o much pronuÌ„ tiation, as is requiÅ¿ite, becauÅ¿e it is of no Å¿mall force, when it is done with modeÅ¿tie: but if it be done with affectatioÌ„, to pleaÅ¿e the hearers & if it hath immodeÅ¿ty mingled with it, as the Å¿haking of the whole bodie, the moouing of the hands, of the feete, and of the armes, and with the turning of the heade altogither affected (although hee may edifie the ruder Å¿ort, becauÅ¿e that oftentimes they are more rauiÅ¿hed with Å¿uch motioÌ„s, theÌ„ with the voice
and inÅ¿truction) hee muÅ¿t auoyd it as much as he can.

The reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e that preachers, which do declare good & profitable things (which do require humilitie) they ought to Å¿hewe in all things, a Å¿ingular modeÅ¿tie. That were more tollerable in courts, wherin matters are pleaded, for lawyers, & rhethoritians, and orators, which handle matters, which may better agree with Å¿uch kinde of Å¿peaking, then with the Å¿acred diuinitie. It is true alÅ¿o, that he muÅ¿t not be Å¿crupulous, as Å¿ome, which would not haue vs to vÅ¿e any geÅ¿ture at all, nor to delight the hearer in any thing.As an honeÅ¿t & profitable geÅ¿ture becoÌ„ meth the Preacher, Å¿o an immodeÅ¿tie vnÅ¿eemely, & he muÅ¿t abÅ¿taine from it. For if the hearer bee delighted with the preacher (vÅ¿ing an honeÅ¿t geÅ¿ture) & taketh a Å¿ingular pleaÅ¿ure in hearing him, yt may alÅ¿o very much edifie, if he heareth with deÅ¿ire: and froÌ„ this delight, there may proceed alÅ¿o Å¿ome frute, that he may receiue, which taketh Å¿uch pleaÅ¿ure in hearing: Å¿o that for this cauÅ¿e, wee may apply our Å¿elues Å¿omewhat to delight the audience. But hee muÅ¿t take heede of one fault, into which hee maye fall, eÅ¿pecially in regard of his voice, that is,How the voyce may be abuÅ¿ed. in making it to reÅ¿ound, and to giue an Eccho, that nothing is heard but the Å¿ound, and litle inÅ¿truction, is gathered of all that is pronounced by Å¿uch a pleaÅ¿ant and delightfull voice. For it is a thing not onely vndecent, but alÅ¿o very
vitious, to pronounce a light and vaine thing with a graue voice, as though it were a matter worthy great commendation, as to Å¿peake of graue and Å¿erious matters with a reÅ¿ounding, and delectable voice. Hee may fall into this extremitie, when being puffed vppe, with I knowe not what opinion of himÅ¿elfe, and of his Å¿ufficiencie, doth deÅ¿piÅ¿e Å¿tudy, Å¿peaking that which commeth into his minde, thinking that he hath Å¿ufficiently preached, although hee neuer much thought vppon that which he Å¿pake. Such be like Å¿ome amongÅ¿t the PhiloÅ¿ophers, who doo not onely boaÅ¿t to knowe any thing, but that they can anÅ¿wer readily to euery demaund, without needing any preparation, or meditation: but as the behauiour of theÅ¿e men, hath iuÅ¿tly bin thought rediculous of many of the Å¿ounder PhiloÅ¿ophers, the cuÅ¿tome of Preachers which goe about to make the like vaunt of their vanitie, is more worthy to be laughed at, and blamed, becauÅ¿e it is almoÅ¿t a thing impoÅ¿Å¿ible to Å¿peake well of an high and Å¿erious matter a long time,The preacher muÅ¿t neuer preach without Å¿tudy. 1 Orat. and to edification, without thinking vpon the Å¿ame before hand. Cicero Å¿aith, that it is profitable Å¿ometime to Å¿peak on the Å¿uddain, but it is more profitable when one is prepared thereunto, becauÅ¿e there cannot be much ioyce in that which is without premeditation.

DemoÅ¿thenes hath better met with this fault,He yt preacheth the word negligeÌ„tly, he procureth the curÅ¿e of God, but he that performeth his dutie with diligence and a good conÅ¿cience, he getteth the bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God. Å¿aying: He is a very bad man that will Å¿peak, or that goeth to Å¿peake Å¿eriouÅ¿ly of waightie matters, without being prepared: If this bee true as it is, into what diÅ¿credit may ye diuine Preacher fall, who dareth, without hauing thought vpon the matter before, go into the Pulpit, to declare, not the word of a King, nor of an earthly Monarch, but of the liuing God? Then ihinke with thy Å¿elfe what a miÅ¿chiefe thou falleÅ¿t into, when thou art guiltie of this fault.

Thou haÅ¿t not to doo with men, but with God, whoÅ¿e perÅ¿on thou doeÅ¿t repreÅ¿ent. If thou beeÅ¿t negligent in his Å¿eruice, dooeÅ¿t thou not thinke with thy Å¿elfe, that GOD which hath Å¿o honoured thee, and exalted thee Å¿o high, as to be his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador or meÅ¿Å¿enger, will not be greeuouÅ¿ly offended with thee? ThinkÅ¿t thou not that IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t who was willing to dy for thee, & for thoÅ¿e Å¿heep that hee hath committed vnto thee, that he will not puniÅ¿h thee for thy flouthfulneÅ¿Å¿e, if thou diÅ¿daineÅ¿t this Å¿o honourable a charge?

Againe, doÅ¿t thou not imagin, that Å¿uch idleneÅ¿Å¿e is deteÅ¿table to the Angelles, who watcheth continually for the preÅ¿eruation of the faithfull? And further will, not thine own conÅ¿cience bee a thouÅ¿and witneÅ¿Å¿es, which
will cruelly torment thee, and accuÅ¿e thee before God of thy negligeÌ„ce, & careleÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, & of ye Å¿mall zeale, which thou beareÅ¿t towards the glory of God? But conÅ¿ider on the contrary Å¿ide, if thou beeÅ¿t feruent in Å¿tudie, to deuide the woord of God with moÅ¿t edification, & that ordinarily thou doÅ¿t not declare the Å¿ame, without preparation, and yt the people which come by heapes to thy Å¿ermons, do returne coÌ„tent, & Å¿atisfied, God, IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, who Å¿eeth thy trauaile, thy diligeÌ„ce, thy zeale for the Å¿aluation of ye faithful, will abundantly bleÅ¿Å¿e thee, the Angels will reioyce, thine own conÅ¿cience will yeeld vnto thee a Å¿ingular coÌ„tentatioÌ„ wil bring vnto thee, Å¿ouereign coÌ„fort, and will alwaies Å¿et thee in the reÅ¿t & tranquilitie of the Å¿oule. All this, with many other reaÅ¿ons may prick thee forward, to the performing of thy dutie, not to go forward in thy calling negligently. But behold alÅ¿o one point which likewiÅ¿e may prouoke thee more chearfully to perform thy duty, yt Å¿eeing that it may Å¿o happen, that thou Å¿halt preach before a great multitude, if thou beeÅ¿t wel prepared, then thou maieÅ¿t more edifie, then thou haÅ¿te done many yeares before, eyther by writing, or otherwiÅ¿e: and therfore thou muÅ¿t take heed that thou dooÅ¿t not let Å¿lip Å¿o good an occaÅ¿ion. To conclude this matter, we may obÅ¿erue, that Å¿eeing that it is a great
paine (as Cicero Å¿aith in his firÅ¿t book de Natura deo:) to Å¿peake alone before a multitude of men, then when euery one ha â€¢ keneth, and that there is almoÅ¿t none which doth not more marke the faultes of the preacher:The preacher muÅ¿t deÅ¿ire of God the Å¿pirit of diÅ¿cretion, when he goeth to expound Gods word. then that which is wel Å¿poken, and if any good leÅ¿Å¿on be giuen, it quickly Å¿lippeth out of the minde of the hearers. It concerneth vs Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to aduiÅ¿e to Å¿peake with feare & great diÅ¿cretion of the Å¿pirit, and before wee begin, we muÅ¿t remember to beg the Å¿ame grace at Gods hand, with ardent and deuout prayer.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the manner of diÅ¿puting.
div.p:
IT is high time nowe to come to the Å¿ecoÌ„d part of the miniÅ¿terie, that is, To conuince the aduerÅ¿aries with Å¿ound doctrine. Vnder this part, we comprehend the diÅ¿putations & coÌ„fereÌ„ces of learned men, & eÅ¿pecially of diuines: for Å¿eeing yt all exerciÅ¿es ought to be ordained (as they are in many places) to frame theÌ„Å¿elues to coÌ„uince thoÅ¿e who do reÅ¿iÅ¿t the truth: wee may very fitly containe Å¿uch diÅ¿putations and conferences,
vnder the forme of reaÅ¿oning. But we vnderÅ¿tand not by theÅ¿e conferences, and diÅ¿putations, onely thoÅ¿e that are vÅ¿ed certaine houres in the vniuerÅ¿ities, or other where, which are not common to euery one, but we vnderÅ¿tand alÅ¿o, and principally, thoÅ¿e which ought to be vÅ¿ed oftentimes, betwixt them which doo apply themÅ¿elues to Å¿ome Å¿tudie, eyther in familiar diÅ¿courÅ¿es in the houÅ¿e, or in walking abroad, or in Å¿um, vpon Å¿uch occations, as may be offered. Wee Å¿ay that Å¿uch conferences are neceÅ¿Å¿ary, becauÅ¿e they are a good meanes to make others acquainted with that knowledge which we haue, or with that which we haue not, and he that can haue conference with them with whome he doth conuerÅ¿e, he may peraduenture knowe them, whom he knoweth not before: by this louing manner of conferring with them.

2. By this conference we may learne much (Å¿o that they be done modeÅ¿tly, and with an affection to Å¿earch the truth of any thing, otherwiÅ¿e they cauÅ¿e more harme then good) for if they that conferre with vs, bee our Å¿uperiours, that is, if they be eÅ¿teemed for great men, we muÅ¿t firmely retaine thoÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons, which they do propoÅ¿e: but if they bee our equalls, and that in conferring with them, we perceiue that they do excell vs, that may engeÌ„der in vs a kinde of holy and lawdable iealouÅ¿ie,
which may Å¿tirre vs the more liuely to applie our Å¿tudie. Moreouer it commeth to paÅ¿Å¿e, that we may better retain thoÅ¿e things, which by conference we do debate vpon by diuers reaÅ¿oÌ„s, theÌ„ thoÅ¿e things that we hear or read oftentimes of our Å¿elues, wherby a great coÌ„moditie redoundeth vnto vs. Thirdly, wheÌ„ we haue Å¿tudied and heaped vp much knowledge, vnleÅ¿Å¿e we do impart the Å¿ame to others by confereÌ„ce, it litle auaileth, & remaineth by vs almoÅ¿t vnprofitable. Further wee may ad, that Å¿uch conferences be neceÅ¿Å¿ary, not only becauÅ¿e our knowledge Å¿hould remaine as it were barren: as principally for theÅ¿e incoÌ„ueniences which ofteÌ„ times happeneth. FirÅ¿t of al, by reaÅ¿oÌ„ we may deceiue our Å¿elues in our knowledge, & how is that? that is, in conceiuing of many things which we read, another maner of vnderÅ¿tanding then we ought, as it falleth out many times amoÌ„g many, who reading certain authors, vnderÅ¿taÌ„deth theÌ„ otherwiÅ¿e then the author meant theÌ„, but by often conference, they may bee made cleare diuers waies. SecoÌ„dly, Å¿eeing yt naturally knowledge puffeth vp, & maketh the moÅ¿t part of men proud, it is great maruell, if thoÅ¿e which haue gotten knowledge, & which are deÅ¿irous to obtain it, become not inÅ¿oleÌ„t, if they liue priuately, without coÌ„municating their gifts with other men: wherof it coÌ„meth, that Å¿uch hauing
a preiudicate opinion of their own Å¿ufficiencie, do deÅ¿piÅ¿e others, & make no reckoning of any but of themÅ¿elues. And this is ye cauÅ¿e, that Å¿uch oftentimes by incouÌ„tring of others in conference, being reprehended and diÅ¿couered to be ignoraÌ„t, they are very much grieued & caÅ¿t down, & this is becauÅ¿e principally they perceiue ye report of their Å¿ufficiencie to be diminiÅ¿hed, and therby to be diÅ¿honored. InÅ¿omuch, that Å¿ome when they come into companie, do bluÅ¿h for Å¿hame: other do purÅ¿ue with deadlye hatred, thoÅ¿e which haue reproued them, other break out into intemperate paÅ¿Å¿ions, & do defend by al means that errour, whereof they were reproued, although it be very foule & monÅ¿trous, imagining by that Å¿tifneÅ¿Å¿e in opinion, in Å¿ome Å¿ort to recouer that honour, which they thinke to be made leÅ¿Å¿e: wherby ofteÌ„times they fal into great & horrible miÅ¿chiefs. To be brief, Å¿uch accidents do caÅ¿t them headlong into Å¿traÌ„ge troubles, and perturbations of the Å¿oule, as we may Å¿ee by experience, & many can be good and Å¿ufficient witneÅ¿Å¿es hereof. But when one is accuÅ¿tomed to be reproued, and to reproue, or to be ouercome, or to ouercome, it is profitable both for him that is ouercome, & reproued: as for him that doth ouercome, or reproue. It is profitable for him yt is ouercom, or reproued, in this, that when he is reproued in Å¿om reaÅ¿oning, as may fal out, it is not grieuous
to him at al, becauÅ¿e he is accuÅ¿tomed to it: but coÌ„trarie, it is pleaÅ¿ant, & profitable, becauÅ¿e by this means he learneth, according to the Å¿aying of one of ye fathers, that when one is reproued, he is inÅ¿tructed. It is profitable alÅ¿o for him yt doth reproue & ouercome, in this that being accuÅ¿tomed to ouercome, and to be ouercome, he doth not therfore deÅ¿piÅ¿e him which is ouercome, or reproued, althogh he be farre more Å¿ufficient then him: becauÅ¿e that in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e, if he Å¿hould deÅ¿piÅ¿e him, it might Å¿o come to paÅ¿Å¿e, that being reproued, or ouercome, he Å¿hould fal into the Å¿ame contempt, vnto which he wold bring him, whom he hath reproued, or ouercome. And by this means the vanitie of them may be corrected, who hauing reproued or taught any one in Å¿ome childiÅ¿h thing, & of Å¿ome Å¿mall importaÌ„ce, do afterward make their boaÅ¿ts & brags of it, to their own praiÅ¿e, & to the coÌ„tempt of them, whom they haue reproued or taught: in which they do many times rather Å¿hewe their Å¿ottiÅ¿hnes, and ignorance, then their learning and wiÅ¿dome. To what end then Å¿uch conferences Å¿erueth, euery one may diÅ¿cerne by theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons Å¿et downe: & aboue all things (the Å¿ame being as that oyntment called vnguentum catholicum, to purge vs of that folly, and imaginarie fantaÅ¿ie, which wee conceiue ordinarily of our owne Å¿ufficiencie,) we may
conclude, that the exerciÅ¿e of them is Å¿o profitable,The preacher muÅ¿t be skilfull in diÅ¿puting as the want of them is hurtfull. But Å¿eeing that wee handle here principally the maner of diÅ¿puting, which is altogether neceÅ¿Å¿ary for theÌ„ which deÅ¿ire the office of a preacher, to conuince the gainÅ¿ayers of the truth: we Å¿ay generally, yt a preacher muÅ¿t not leÅ¿Å¿e apply his Å¿tudy, diligently to attain vnto the art of diÅ¿puting, to be able to coÌ„uince, theÌ„ to the faculty of preaching with coÌ„mendation. And the rather at this day, becauÅ¿e we liue in Å¿uch an age, in which the truth is Å¿o obÅ¿cured and inwrapped, in Å¿uch craftie Å¿ubtilties, that the Å¿imple and ignorant men, are made to beleeue, that light is darkeneÅ¿Å¿e, and truth falÅ¿hood: Å¿o yt it is aboue al things neceÅ¿Å¿ary, that the preacher be endued with the knowledge of diÅ¿puting, to defend the truth againÅ¿t the Å¿ubtile practiÅ¿es of ye aduerÅ¿aries of the Å¿ame. But here he muÅ¿t take heed of an extremity, that in Å¿teed of being a good diÅ¿puter,SophiÅ¿trie burteth much. he becomes not a SophiÅ¿ter. This extremitie is dangerous for two reaÅ¿ons: the firÅ¿t is, that he ye learneth it, trauaileth greatly to attain it, & wheÌ„ he hath gotten ye Å¿ame, it profiteth him nothing at all, but greatly hurteth him. For we Å¿ee by experience, that they that are as it were drunkeÌ„ with the Å¿ame, thinking themÅ¿elues vnequall to others, they become for the moÅ¿t part very proude & inÅ¿olent, ful
of vaine glorie, which be great hinderances to attaine vnto any Å¿oundneÅ¿Å¿e in learning. There bee Å¿ome that compare verie fitlie the SophiÅ¿ter vnto a certaine beaÅ¿t called BonaÅ¿us, who carrieth hornes which Å¿erue him ro no vÅ¿e, but are burdenÅ¿ome, becauÅ¿e they are inwrapped the one within the other: in like maner, SophiÅ¿ters haue logick Å¿o intricate, that it cannot Å¿erue their turnes, but rather do them much harme. The Å¿econd reaÅ¿on is, that it is alÅ¿o hurtfull, as well to others, as to theÌ„Å¿elues. For they vnto whom they Å¿peak, for the moÅ¿t parte cannot vnderÅ¿tand what they Å¿ay, and that which is worÅ¿e, they do often Å¿educe & deceiue many, who cannot conceiue or iudge of theyr Å¿ubtilties. And wee muÅ¿t not bee miÅ¿taken, as though we blamed logicke, as men ignorant of the Å¿ame: for we know by experieÌ„ce, yt it is Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿arie for a Preacher, that without it, he caÌ„ not not onelie conuince the gainÅ¿ayers, but alÅ¿o he cannot handle the word of God with good order & diÅ¿poÅ¿itioÌ„:A fit Å¿imilitude, Å¿hewing the vÅ¿e of logicke, when it is Å¿oberly Å¿tudied, and the abuÅ¿e in the exceÅ¿Å¿e. but we do find fault with the exceÅ¿Å¿e, into which many enter after this Å¿tudy, becauÅ¿e yt the exceÅ¿Å¿e doth much and more harme, then a meane knowledge therof doth good. For euen as the Iuy leaues wheÌ„ they are applyed outwardly to ye Å¿inows, do very much eaÅ¿e the pain, but if one drink the iuice of the hearb, it hurteth them: as certain
natural philoÅ¿ophers haue Å¿aid: euen Å¿o if one be exceÅ¿Å¿iue in the Å¿tudy of logick, it Å¿hal greatly hinder his other Å¿tudies, & eÅ¿pecially his godlines: but if he Å¿hal lightly touch it as it were without, he Å¿hall further his learning. It is truely Å¿aid,Cannon of Pope Vrban. that Å¿eeing that SophiÅ¿trie is deuiÅ¿ed, as a certaine Cannon Å¿aieth, not to build, but to deÅ¿troy, not to make ye truth manifeÅ¿t, but to obÅ¿cure it, and that the preacher muÅ¿t defend it againÅ¿t all the obÅ¿tacles therof, it is good that he vnderÅ¿taÌ„deth SophiÅ¿try, not to vÅ¿e it to deceiue others, but to defende himÅ¿elfe, and that they vÅ¿e it as phiÅ¿itions doo venimous hearbs: that is, as it is profitable for them to know them, that they carefully take heed of them, and that they may vÅ¿e them (if occaÅ¿ion Å¿erueth) in Å¿ome cauÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿itie, The PaÅ¿tor alÅ¿o muÅ¿t not bee ignoraunt of SophiÅ¿trie, to the ende hee may maintaine the Å¿ounde doctrine againÅ¿t all SophiÅ¿ters. But if hee that deÅ¿ireth to bee a preacher, wil excell in this Arte, not contenting himÅ¿elfe with a meane knowledge therein, hee may Å¿pend much of his time vnprofitably, & wheÌ„ he hath wel Å¿weat at it, he Å¿hall find no great vÅ¿e thereof. For it is not the right way to come to a Å¿ound knowledge, but a wrong and crooked way, in which all they that haue walked, they haue Å¿trangely erred, as we may Å¿ee at this day many, who affecting Å¿ounde
knowledge, haue Å¿tayed too long in this, and that for want of iudgement, which is the cauÅ¿e they trauaile much, and yet Å¿til remain barren. This is the complaint of an auncient Doctor, Å¿aying:Hug. 3. DidaÅ¿co. Whereof commeth it to paÅ¿Å¿e, that Å¿o great a multitude of learners, of which many haue a good Å¿pirit, and doo vÅ¿e exerciÅ¿e, and yet verie fewe are founde which doo attaine vnto true knowledge: we muÅ¿t know that in euerie action whatÅ¿oeuer it bee, we muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue two things. The firÅ¿t is, to knowe the woorke which one goeth about to doo: The Å¿econd is, to be acquainted with the meanes of compaÅ¿Å¿ing the Å¿ame: for theÅ¿e two thinges muÅ¿t bee Å¿o knitte together, that the one without the other is vnprofitable. After hee addeth, that wiÅ¿edom is better then force, for wiÅ¿edome doth that by and by, which force is a long time in dooing.To attaine Å¿ound knowledge, we muÅ¿t proceede in our Å¿tudies with iudgement. AlÅ¿o in euerie Å¿tudy whatÅ¿oeuer it bee, hee that laboureth without order and diÅ¿cretion, hee trauaileth well, but he bringeth not his Å¿tudy to that perfection as is conuenient, and he is like vnto him that beateth the aire, or caÅ¿teth Å¿tones againÅ¿t the wind. Looke vpon (Å¿aith he a little after) two men walking in the forreÅ¿t, the one going in a crooked way, the other in a plaine, both go to the Å¿ame place by diuers wayes, but both do not a like, but he that goeth the right way

In what happineÅ¿Å¿e may hee thinke himÅ¿elfe to bee, that is in Å¿ome meaÅ¿ure capable to Å¿erue God in this calling.

div.head: CHAP. XI. An Exhortation to yong men, to bende theyr Studies to the holy MiniÅ¿trie, with a confutation of thoÅ¿e common obiections which doo diÅ¿courage them.

IN truth now, beeing in the way liuely to exhort the youth to take vpon them this holy charge, from which they may be diÅ¿couraged by reaÅ¿on of the infinite difficulties which are preÅ¿ented before them, wee doo it the more willingly,
becauÅ¿e wee deÅ¿ire nothing more then the glorie of God, and the Å¿aluation of our Brethren, both which, cannot bee better furthered then by this charge. But alas, which way Å¿hall I beginne? The beautie, dignitie, and incomparable profite of the Å¿ame, ought to be as Å¿harpe Å¿purres, to Å¿tirre vppe euerie one. When one deÅ¿ireth that Å¿ome Å¿houlde applie themÅ¿elues vnto thoÅ¿e things, which doo appeare Å¿o good in outward Å¿hew, to allure and draw men thereunto, it is verie neceÅ¿Å¿arie to vÅ¿e many reaÅ¿ons and arguments, to bring them thereunto, and to pricke them forward: but in things that be of themÅ¿elues maruailous, excellent, and verie profitable, euerie one ought to embrace them of his owne accord. There is no lightneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿o glorious, as that of the MiniÅ¿trie, there is no calling, to bee compared thereunto, in dignitie and profite: wherof then commeth it to paÅ¿Å¿e, that many do Å¿o little regard it? Plato hath Å¿ayde that vertue is Å¿o fayre, that if her beautie could be diÅ¿cerned with theÅ¿e corporall eyes, it would prouoke great loue of itÅ¿elf: what difference is there between the beauty of the miniÅ¿trie,A confutation of the obiection of the ambitious. and yt of morall vertue? if one would propoÅ¿e vnto himÅ¿elf the litle reckoning & account, which is ordinarily made of miniÅ¿ters, hee would deteÅ¿t the Å¿ame: we anÅ¿wer yt this is the
obiection of an ambitious man, and to correct this ambition, thou muÅ¿t Å¿et before thy eyes, that the honour which thou doÅ¿t deÅ¿ire and gape after, it is worldly and vaine. And if it bee Å¿o, thou wanteÅ¿t iudgement in deÅ¿iring it, and in that thou Å¿heweÅ¿t the follie and vanitie of thy minde. Further, thou muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, that the honour which thou dreameÅ¿t of, to be in Å¿ome other calling, is often times troubleÅ¿ome, greeuous, which is deare before it bee gotten, and hard to bee kept. He that will be a phiÅ¿itian, how many trauailes & cares muÅ¿t he paÅ¿Å¿e through? how often muÅ¿t he watch in the night, before he can attaine his purpoÅ¿e, & when he thinketh that he hath attained it, how muÅ¿t he toile & labor to be knowne, & to be had in eÅ¿timation? when he is once knowne, & Å¿ought after for his skill, is he then more quiet & at reÅ¿t? muÅ¿t he not Å¿ometime riÅ¿e out of his bed to help his patient? he muÅ¿t make haÅ¿te, he muÅ¿t ride in poÅ¿t many times with the daunger of the loÅ¿Å¿e of his own health: what more? wheÌ„ he coÌ„meth to viÅ¿it his patient, what Å¿auours is he conÅ¿trained to Å¿mel? & the better to know the qualitie of ye diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, & the iÅ¿Å¿ue therof, he muÅ¿t Å¿omtime view the verie excrements of the Å¿ick man, and taÅ¿te them: what pleaÅ¿ure I pray you, or what delight caÌ„ he take in that? doth the lawyer endure leÅ¿Å¿e trauels? doth he

Moreouer, thou muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, that all theÅ¿e affayres for which they are Å¿o tormented, and continually vexed, they are about earthly things, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently, all the honor & profit which they get by the Å¿ame, is tranÅ¿itory, and vaniÅ¿h away as the Å¿moake. To conclude, meditate thou vpon this, for thy comfort, that thou art honoured in the adminiÅ¿tration of thy miniÅ¿terie, of all thoÅ¿e that are wiÅ¿e, and feare God: and Å¿eeing that is the true honour, which commeth froÌ„ good men, and not from Å¿enÅ¿ual men, we may conclude, that thou haÅ¿t more honor then the other. Secondly, think with thy Å¿elf, that there is at this day, almoÅ¿t no men, which are addicted to any other Å¿tudy, as to any arte mechanick, who doo finde more eaÅ¿ily, honeÅ¿t conditions

In the fourth place, thou muÅ¿t meditate, that GGD is the plentifull rewarder of all the MiniÅ¿ters of GOD, and thou muÅ¿t thinke vppon all thoÅ¿e excellent promiÅ¿es of GOD, which hee maketh in his worde, to nouriÅ¿h all liuing creatures. To make an ende of this point, Å¿ette before thine eyes, that if they abound not in temporall, and earthly goods: yet they are riche in the knowledge of the word of God, in the vnderÅ¿tanding, and reuealing of his Å¿ecrets, which are the true riches of the Å¿oule: and Å¿eeing that thoÅ¿e be the true riches, coÌ„Å¿ider that the more thou aboundeÅ¿t with theÌ„, the more thou art truly rich: for theÅ¿e riches wil bring vnto thee Å¿o much ioy and gladneÅ¿Å¿e, as the corporall and worldly goods, doo bring vnto them that poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e them, griefe, and care, and Å¿o enioying theÅ¿e true and Å¿incere Å¿pirituall rithes, why doÅ¿t thou take Å¿uch thought for the riches of this world? If another doth reply,A confutation of thoÅ¿e that loue pleaÅ¿ure. that his heart is pulled downe, becauÅ¿e that miniÅ¿ters are ordinarily Å¿orowfull, penÅ¿iue, full of care and melancholy, I may demande of him, why are they more then other men? TheÅ¿e bee vaine and imaginarie fanÅ¿ies, forged in the braine, of I knowe not what worldly men, for they are as ioyfull as other, and it is as lawfull for them as for any other. Seneca Å¿ayth in a certaine place, that we muÅ¿t gouerne our Å¿elues in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that none may think vs too Å¿euere, and again, that none deÅ¿piÅ¿e vs, as thoÅ¿e that be vile & contemptible, & that we muÅ¿t more delight in profitable matters, then in things that be rediculous: & he addeth, that one may mingle Å¿ometime amongÅ¿t graue & Å¿erious matters, thoÅ¿e things that be pleaÅ¿ant, but we muÅ¿t take heed that they bee Å¿o tempered, that they do not diÅ¿credit their honour.
